ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this course to someone who wants help in bridging the gap between disciplines: Classics and Comp. Literature, English and Renaissance Studies. Prof. Quint's unique style broadened my academic perspective quite a bit.

This course has been an invaluable overview of epic, mixing classical, continental and English epic, which I think was its great strength. I would recommend this class strongly as an excellent grounding in the genre.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: The broad scope of the class -- ranging from classical to late-Renaissance epic -- meant that not every text was deeply examined, and that not all of them were useful to my research. Still, I learned a lot about the discipline as a whole by Professor Quint's constantly engaging teaching.

This class, by focussing on reception and on comparative reading, has helped to strengthen my knowledge of the tradition in which early modern epic poets were writing. The critical essays we read each week were always apt and important, and the structure of the class, in which one person responded to the readings each week, gave attention to the secondary reading, which I really enjoyed and appreciated. This class has improved my knowledge of classics as read by early modern poets, an area of interest for me and one to which I will hopefully return.
